In November 2016, the Journal reported that Trump backer American Media, owner of The National Enquirer supermarket tabloid, paid $150,000 to a former Playboy model for her story of an alleged relationship with Trump, which they then chose not to publish.

Stephanie Clifford, who uses the stage name Stormy Daniels, was reportedly paid $130,000 by Essential Consultants LLC, a Delaware business created by attorney Michael Cohen less than a month before the 2016 presidential election, the Journal said.

The new report was published just before a new poll from NBC and The Wall Street Journal found that Trump's approval rating stands at only 39 percent — the lowest number in the survey's history for any modern president after one year in office.

In addition, Trump and Congress are mired in a fight over government spending, immigration and children's health insurance as the threat of a government shutdown loomed Friday — the eve of the first anniversary of Trump's inauguration.

A lawyer for then-candidate Donald Trumpestablished a private limited liability company in October 2016 to pay off an adult film star to keep her silent about an alleged extramarital affair with Trump, The Wall Street Journal reported.
He also sent the newspaper a statement signed by Daniels that denied she had a "sexual and/or romantic" relationship with Trump or that she received "hush money from Donald Trump."
The company issued a draft settlement pact to Clifford, referring to her by the pseudonym "Peggy Peterson," according to Slate, which published photos of the document.
As part of the settlement, Clifford signed a nondisclosure agreement with Cohen, precluding her from discussing the affair publicly, the Journal reported.
CNBC left multiple messages for him at the Republican National Committee, where he is deputy chairman of the RNC's finance leadership team.
The intrigue surrounding an alleged affair between Trump and Clifford is not the first time reports emerged about his relationships.
In 2011, Clifford detailed her alleged 2006 dalliance with Trump, in a lengthy interview with gossip magazine In Touch Weekly.
Clifford's lawyer, Keith Davidson, did not immediately respond to a request for comment.
The White House did not immediately respond to multiple requests for comment.
The newspaper cited corporate records and sources familiar with the matter.
American Media denies that the payment was hush money.
Cohen has aggressively disputed the Journal's reports.
Trump married his current wife, Melania, in 2005.
Read the full Wall Street Journal report here.
Their son, Barron, was born in March 2006.
In Touch published the interview Friday.
Cohen could not be reached for comment.
